title: SCANA Q4 2008 Earnings Call Transcript
body: SCANA Corp. (NYSE:SCG) Q4 2008 Earnings Call February 12, 2009  9:00 AM ET
Executives
Betty Best - Director of Financial Planning and Investor Relations
Jimmy Addison - Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer
Kevin B. Marsh - President and Chief Operating Officer, South Carolina Electric & Gas Company
Analysts
Steve Fleishman - Catapult Capital
Dan Jenkins - State of Wisconsin
Jonathan Reeder - Wachovia Securities
Operator

Good afternoon ladies and gentlemen. Thank you for standing by. My name is Lacy, and I'll be your conference facilitator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to SCANA Corporations Conference Call. All lines have been placed on mute to prevent any background noise. After the speakers' remarks, there will be a question-and-answer period. (Operator Instructions). As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded on Thursday, February 12, 2009. Anyone who does not consent to the taping may drop off the line at this time.
I would now like to turn the call over to Betty Best, Director of Financial Planning and Investor Relations. Please proceed.
Betty Best
Thanks Lacy, and good morning. I'd like to welcome everyone to our earnings conference call, including those who are joining us on the webcast.

Earlier today, we announced results for the fourth quarter and full year of 2008. In just a minute, Jimmy Addison, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer will review those results, give updates on certain operational issues, as well as our new nuclear program and respond to questions. The earnings press release that we will refer to in this conference call is available on our website at scana.com.

I would like to remind everyone that certain statements that maybe made during today's call which are not statements of historical facts are considered forward-looking statements and are subject to a number of risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those indicated by such forward-looking statements. Among those risks and uncertainties are those discussed in the company's SEC filings. The company does not recognize an obligation to update any forward-looking statements.
I will now turn the call over to Jimmy.
Jimmy Addison

Thanks Betty, and good morning. I would also like to welcome each of you to our call. This morning we reported 2008 full year earnings of $2.95 per share compared to $2.74 per share in 2007. The growth in 2008 earnings per share represents a 7.7% increase over 2007 and met our guidance.

For the fourth quarter of 2008 we reported earnings of $0.73 per share, down slightly from $0.75 per share in the same quarter of 2007. Table summarizing earnings variances and sales metrics for the quarter and full year are provided in the earnings press release.

The $0.21 per share increase in earnings for the year was driven primarily by the retail electric rate increase and the favorable impact of continued customer growth in both Carolinas, which offset increased expenses for operations and maintenance, interest and property taxes. The $0.02 per share erosion in the fourth quarter was primarily a result of the impact of slightly higher OEM expense and reduced electric usage, which more than offset improved electric margins driven by the retail electric rate increase and the favorable impact of continued customer growth.

We are very pleased to have delivered strong financial results and great value for our shareholders despite the economic challenges and temperate weather we experienced, especially during the fourth quarter.

Concerning customer growth, we're seeing a reduction in growth, but still growth in most of our business. In our electric service area SCE&G's annual customer growth declined from 2.6% or about 16,000 customers in 2007 to 1.6% or about 10,000 customers in 2008.

In our regulated gas businesses, SCE&G's customer growth declined from 1.8% or 5,300 customers in 2007 to 1.5% or 4,600 customers in 2008. While PSNC's customer growth declined from 3.6% or about 16,000 customers in 2007 to 2.3% or about 11,000 customers in 2008.

Looking at our non-regulated gas businesses, SCANA Energy, a Georgia natural gas marketer experienced a 5% customer decline or about 25,000 customers in 2008 due to more intense competition. However, we've implemented an aggressive marketing campaign over the last several months and have attracted the majority of market switches during that period.

Our customer growth remained a positive contributor to earnings of $0.09 per share, weather normalized usage for our residential electric customers was down between 1 and 2% from 2007, for an estimated earnings impact of about $0.05 per share. We are closely monitoring inactive accounts and are pleased that we have seen the material increase in those numbers as some others have reported.

For our long-term wholesale and our off-system customers, energy sales were down $0.03 per share for 2008 due to the overall market demand for electricity. Also, the demand for electricity has decreased so has the price of natural gas. Natural Gas is now at a price that combines cycle generation is competitive with most company's base load coal units.

We estimate that weather negatively impacted earnings $0.06 per share in 2008 compared to normal. In 2007, we estimate weather was $0.09 below normal, so the year-over-year impact was $0.03 per share improvement.

Turning now to the economy. Like most other regions, the southeast has not been immune to the current recession. Businesses scrambling to cut calls are taking a painful toll on our original labor market. December preliminary unemployment numbers for our service territories range from 8.1% in Georgia to 9.5% in South Carolina.

Early in 2008, we began efforts to adapt and respond to what originally was expected to be an economic slowdown. As the year unfolded we took progressively more stringent steps as the financial markets and the residential construction sector both collapsed and the unemployment in the manufacturing sector began to decline. These actions have enabled us to offset some of the negative impacts from the slower economy in milder weather.
We recognized that we must continued to use our resources wisely while meeting our customers' energy requirement safely, reliably and at the lowest cost possible over the long term.

As you may be aware, yesterday the South Carolina PSC approved our nuclear application. I've asked Kevin Marsh, President of SCE&G, to join me on the call today and will turn it over to him in a few minutes for more details on this matter as well as our update on where we stand with the NRC at the federal level. But before I leave nuclear, I would like to give you an update on our DOE loan guarantee applications.

On September 26th, SCE&G filed a Part I application for the loan guarantee under the Energy Policy Act 2005 to support the construction of the two new nuclear units. On October the 2nd, the DOE announced it had received 19 Part I applications from 17 electric power companies. After reviewing the Part I submissions, the DOE assigned initial rankings of the projects based on the factors summarized in each solicitation. We received notification in late November that SCE&G has been initially ranked second.

The DOE identified several factors that had a significant impact on our assessment. First, SCE&G's strong financial commitment in history of three decades of joint operations with our proposed partners Santee Cooper, back in our clear commitment to the project and to nuclear power as a low cost alternative.

Third, state and regulatory authorities are supportive of nuclear power and a few willing to provide CWIP in rate base. Fourth, demand in our region is strong and growing; and fifth, we have assigned EPC contract. We filed the Part II submission of the application on December 19th. The next step is an oral presentation which is scheduled for later this month.

Moving now to sources of capital. The challenging conditions during 2008 tested utilities, liquidity and their ability to access short-term funding sources. We are pleased that all of the banks and our revolving credit facility is fully funded our request withdrawals. As of December 31st, we have drawn approximately $450 million from our $1.1 billion facility. We have approximately $80 million in commercial paper borrowings outstanding and approximately $250 million in cash and temporary investments.

We regularly monitored the commercial paper and short-term credit markets to optimize the timing repayment of the outstanding balance on withdrawals while maintaining the appropriate levels of liquidity for the company.

At December 31st, we had net availability liquidity of approximately $800 million and our revolving credit facilities are in place until December 2011. We also successfully issued $300 million of first mortgage bonds in September at a rate of 6.5% during a difficult period of time. Our overall debt portfolio has weighted average maturity of over 13 years and there is an average of 5.62%.

All of our long-term debt other than our facility withdrawals bears fixed interest rates. We continued to believe that it's most prudent for our costumers to finance our long-term assets with long-term fixed rate instruments.

To further preserve our liquidity we have vigorously reviewed our CapEx and operating costs for 2009, and have adjusted where we can without impacting safety, reliability and core costumer service. I'll speak a bit more about CapEx and 2009 expectations in a few minutes.

Another source of cash I mentioned during our last quarterly call relates to the conversion of our stock plans to original issue. Since July 1 of 2008, shares of the company stock purchased on behalf of participants in our investor plus and 401(k) plans are being acquired through original issue shares rather than on the open market. This provided over $40 million of additional cash equity during 2008, and is expected to provide about twice that amount annually for 2009 and forward, due primarily to new nuclear construction plans we anticipate keeping this strategy in place for the foreseeable future.

The minimally dilutive effect of these shares was considered in preparing our 2009 earnings guidance and our future nuclear revised rate filings will provide for the periodic update of our capital structure to help mitigate future dilution and to incorporate additional debt issuances.

In late December, it was announced that SCANA was selected to replace Merrill Lynch in the S&P 500 Index effective December 31st. Inclusion in this Index is attributed to the hard work of our employees and speaks to the strength of our strategic business model and the execution of the long-term fundamentals that we build on company all. In quick response to this action by S&P, the company issued 2.875 million shares, raising over $100 million with no noticeable pressure on our stocks' market value.
In fact, our stock increased approximately 5% from the period of eagerly prior to the S&P announcement to the pricing of the deal.

We previously indicated our intend to finance capital expenditures for our new nuclear units to a roughly equal combination of debt and equity financing and we had expected to conduct an equity offering during the second quarter of 2009. However, due to the minimal period of additional months outstanding and the more efficient execution in this type transaction, company decided to sell its common stock sooner than previously contemplated.

With the reduction of Cap Expense plan for 2009 and planned operating cost reductions, this transaction makes it unlikely that we will need to raise additional equity in 2009 beyond that issue through our investor plus and 401(k) plans.
As we look forward to 2009, our focus continues to be very cautious and conservative in both operations and finance, while maintaining our standards for customer service, reliability and safety.

In preparing our guidance for 2009, we considered the operating results of the latter months of 2008, projected production of our largest industrial customers, known changes in property taxes, governmental fees, healthcare costs, pension costs and other major expense categories.

We are issuing preliminary guidance for 2009 earnings of $2.65 to $2.95 per common share. This guidance assumes normal weather in our electric and natural gas service areas for the balance of 2009, with the minimal call growth in the regulated jurisdictions and an effective tax rate of approximately 35%.

Core to our assumptions, our electric customer growth and usage at the residential and commercial level and loss of industrial base. Specifically we have assumed our overall electric margin for 2009 is about $10 million or $0.05 per share less than 2008. Components of this decrease are: first, we assume no residential and commercial growth even though we continued to add customers over the last few months. Second, we've assumed all industrial reductions announced to-date are in place for the entire year.

Third, we've assumed that our wholesale contract for approximately 190 megawatts of capacity expires on April 30th. Our guidance 2009 assumes revenue stream for the last eight months of the year, and assumes we do not resale the capacity otherwise. We estimate the impact to be about $0.06 per share. Any placement of this capacity and related energy elsewhere would mitigate the impact. And fourth, we assumed only growth in margins comes from the base load review back increases in late March and the first revise rate adjustment, November 1st of approximately 2.8%. In aggregate we estimate these two increases will contribute $0.07 per share to 2009 earnings.

Other key drivers for 2009 include no further erosion in the industrial sector, no electric base rate increases during 2009, continued company wide efforts to control O&M costs, and sustained profitability of non-regulated business. Of course, we will continue to monitor the economy and other developments. As we move through 2009 getting additional clarity on drivers like customer growth, usage, market conditions et cetera, we expect to narrow this band.

Moving now to some other items, SCANA Energy's current term serving as Georgia's sole regulated provider of natural gas ends August 31st this year. This is a role that company has had since the regulated provider program began in 2002. SCANA Energy was one of only two marketers pre-qualified by the Georgia Public Service Commission to file a bid for this business. Bid packages were due January 20 and we expect a decision by the Commission in early March.

While this piece of the Georgia business isn't material to our annual operating results, we believe it is important that someone appropriately serve these customers in order for the broader market to have stability. We believe SCANA is best positioned to provide this stability.

SCANA has experienced significant declines in our defined benefit pension assets due to the significant declines in the broad market. However, as we had approximately $1.32 in assets for every dollar of liability at the beginning of the year, we remained in better shape in most.
As of December 31st, we had a simple funded ratio of 89% in an asset smooth ratio which is used for funding purposes of 107%, meaning we will not have to make cash contribution during 2009.

The decline in pension assets will however impact our non-cash pension expense. As a significant partial mitigation of this impact, we recently received an important ruling from the South Carolina PSC, allowing us to defer incremental pension expense above that included in current rates for both of our South Carolina regulated businesses. These calls will deferred until our next base rate filing, at which time the accumulated deferred cost will be addressed prospectively.
Considering this important regulatory order, we estimate our 2009 pension expense across all of our businesses will increase our pre-tax cost by approximately $12 million or $0.06 per share.

For 2009, we continued to take all possible steps to manage expenses while still providing the safe and reliable service our customers expect. Actions taken in 2009 include salary freezes for exempt employees, hiring freezes across most departments and holding non-labor O&M spending for 2009 to amounts which are at or below 2008 levels.

Regarding capital projects. Currently, we have scrubbers under construction at our Wateree and Williams plants. We are pleased to report that both are currently ahead of schedule and on budget. Additionally, the selected catalytic reduction project was recently completed in our coke generating station on schedule and on budget. These three projects in total comprise nearly the entire $400 million environmental CapEx budget through 2010 that we shared with you back in May.

In October, we received an important order from the PSC, allowing us to defer oil costs including depreciation and property taxes on these projects until the projects are closed into rates as part of our next base rate proceedings.

Turning now to our capital expenditures. We are carefully reviewing our CapEx projects for the coming three years to determine those that can be deferred until we see signs of economic recovery in our territory. We looked very hard at capital projects related to low growth, especially in transmission and distribution and we reduced capital... planned capital expenditures where we could do so without compromising the guidelines established with service level, safety and reliability.

While we cannot predict full impact of the current economic and financial crisis, we continued to see costumer growth in our regulated electric and gas service territories and must respond to this growth. Our forecast continued to show that we will need the additional generations, our new nuclear units will provide in order to support load growth in our system.

In fact, a review of the recessions of the last several decades consistently shows declining electrical consumption during the recession, followed by post-recession robust growth. We have to be prepared for this long-term growth to provide the energy needed for both our residential costumers and the commercial and industrial segments which will support the underlying jobs creation.

We see our generation expansion program as a long-term investment and the future of our costumers and our state, so that dependable, non-emitting energy is available for a growing service territory. We are pleased that the South Carolina Public Service Commission and Office of Regulatory Staff had concurred.

While we have made some preliminary reductions in our forecasts, we have not completed the review. Our detailed CapEx forecast will be provided in our 10-K filling later this month, and is subject to further revisions until we can quantify the full impact of the DLI (ph) decision yesterday.

Finally, I would like to take a few moments to discuss our financing plans for 2009. In terms of debt maturities and financing needs, SCE&G has one first mortgage bond of $100 million maturing in March that we expect to refinance in the second quarter. We expect to upsize this issue somewhat, to pay down short-term debt. We also expect one another mortgage bond financing in the third quarter.

Our total anticipated debt financing for SCE&G in 2009 are not expected to exceed $450 million, all in the form of first mortgage bonds. As I said earlier, we do not expect to issue additional equity during 2009 other than through the stock plans.
I would now like to turn the call over to Kevin for a thorough update on our nuclear project.
Kevin B. Marsh
Thanks Jimmy, and good morning. Yesterday, the South Carolina Public Service Commission ruled on our base load review application for the construction of two new Westinghouse AP1000 Nuclear Plants.

There are two major components to the decision: first, the commission had to approve the citing of the new plants under the utility facility citing an Environmental Protection Act. Under this Act, Commission must first approve the need for the facility. Second, determine the proposed units serve the interest of system economy and reliability. And third, make an evaluation of the environmental impacts.

In this decision, the Commission approved the citing of the new units, and noted that the evidence presented in the case shows that the size, type, location, and technology of the units are the preferable means of doing so, with the greatest economy and reliability, and with the least impact on the environment.

Next, the commission needed to make a decision under the Base Load Review Act. Under provisions of the Act, the Commission was required to conduct a full preconstruction prudency review of the proposed units and the EPC contract, under which they will be built. Although, we do not have the file order with all of the details, we understand that basic provisions are revert to be. One, approval of the two plants as requested with South Carolina Electric & Gas owning 55% of the units.

Two, approval of the initial rate increase of 7.8 million, or 0.4% related to recovery of the cost of capital on our project expenditures through June 30, 2008. Third, approval of an 18 month construction schedule contingency applicable to the project milestones schedule, or components of the milestone schedule as presented by the company and the hearings. And four, a directive to complete the current study of potential demand side management programs, as testified to by the company and to present the commission with a viable proposal to achieve measurable and sustainable gains in energy efficiency for all of the company's customer classes. This proposal is to be filed with the Commission by June 30, 2009 which is consistent with the mid-summer date offered by the company in the hearings.
You can access the full text of the commission's directive in this case on the SCANA website, on the Webcast & Presentations page.

We are pleased with the Commission's decision in this case, and believe they are approval of our request to build the new nuclear plants is a key milestone and our efforts to meet South Carolina's growing needs proclaim reliable energy.
We expect to hold a separate, more detailed webcast on this matter after we received the written order from the commission which is due by February 28th.
And now let me give you a quick update on a related filing with the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

On March 31, 2008, we submitted our combined construction and operating license or COL application to the NRC. This COL application for the two new units was reviewed for completeness by the NRC and docketed on July 31, 2008.
On September 26th, the NRC issued a 30 month review schedule from the docketing date to the issuance of the Safety Evaluation Report, which will signify a satisfactory completion of their review.

Both the environmental and safety reviews by the NRC continued to be in progress, and should support a COL issuance by July 1, 2011. This date would support both the project schedule and the unit two and unit three substantial completion dates for the two new units in 2016 and 2019 respectively.
I'll now turn the call back over to Jimmy.
Jimmy Addison

Thanks Kevin. In closing, 2008 was a very successful year for our company in many respects. From an operational perspective, we continued to experience customer growth in our electric and natural gas utility business. Our generating plants performed safely, reliably and efficiently.

In our natural gas operations SCANA Energy maintained its position as a second largest marketer in Georgia. We continued to receive reasonable and timely support in each of our regulated utility jurisdictions.

In North Carolina, the Commission issued an order approving an increase in PSNC's retail and natural gas base rates in addition to allowing PSNC to implement a rate decoupling mechanism for usage tracker that severs the link between revenues and the amount of natural gas sold. This tracker allows the company to periodically adjust its base rates when changes in costumer consumption occur.

In South Carolina, the PSC approved an increase in SCE&G's retail gas base rates under the Rate Stabilization Act. Due to the impact of substantially lower gas costs, even after the increases in base rates, retail gas rates today are approximately 12% lower of PSNC and 25% lower at SCE&G than they were this time last year.

We created additional value for our shareholders by growing EPS by nearly 7.7% and increasing the cash dividend on our common stock about 4.5%. Finally, we made tremendous progress with our nuclear projects.
As Kevin has discussed, we now have the state processes in place to proceed with the facilities needed by our costumers, resulting in strategic shareholder value for years to come.
That concludes our prepared remarks. And we'll now be glad to respond to any questions or comments you may have.

Yeah, hi guys. This is Steve Fleishman. How are you?

Great. How about you?

Right.

Jimmy Addison
No, what we're assuming is we're working off of '08's actual and of course we're projecting '09 as normal weather. So it's working off of '08.

Jimmy Addison

Jimmy Addison

Jimmy Addison
It would have.

Jimmy Addison
Correct.

Okay. And then, just overall when you look at the pressure on '09 versus '08, is pretty much all of it at SCE&G or is there some pressure at Georgia and some of these other businesses as a really all to utility?
Jimmy Addison

Steve, I think the economy is fairly similarly and all three of our major jurisdictions here. The, for example, the unemployment rates we discussed range from 8.1% in Georgia to 9.5% in South Carolina.

On the other hand Georgia's housing market rose substantially more than South Carolina's did and has therefore fallen more. So there are different factors impacting it. But, I think the issue of customer usage and the issue of slowing growth of applies to all three territories.

Okay.

And we've had relatively leasing of a minor, but recent increases in the LDC gas businesses in November, both in North Carolina and South Carolina. So those are... you are going to get a full 12 months of that in 2009. Whereas, as I said, we don't anticipate increasing rates in the electric business during 2009. So you've got the timing of that impacting it.
And of course in Georgia, we lost by about 25,000 customers year-over-year from 12 months ago. But we've really gained several in the last three months. We did on a good trend there.
Steve Fleishman - Catapult Capital
Okay. So that shouldn't be a big factor then?
Jimmy Addison

It should not. And even in January, we just looked at some numbers a couple of days ago. And one of our core assumptions in this March, and that you are asking about it, that we add not one new residential customer beyond this December 1st... or December 31st. And we're still adding those customers. In January for example, we added 4 to 500 electric customers, about 600 gas customers in South Carolina, and about 1,900 gas customers in North Carolina. So we're still seeing the growth and that's important. We're just... we're naturally in accordance with our culture, conservative about this and giving a broader range because of that.
Steve Fleishman - Catapult Capital
Okay. One another question on the growth rate.
Jimmy Addison
Yes.
Steve Fleishman - Catapult Capital
The 4 to 6% growth rate.
Jimmy Addison
Yes.
Steve Fleishman - Catapult Capital
What is the base here for that 4 to 6% growth rate?
Jimmy Addison

Well, it's an ongoing long-term period. If you look at any one point in time, if you look over three to five year period, you ought to see the growth rate in that range of 4 to 6% and we're still confident that giving the long-term.

Now, we're here in the short-term period where the economy is down, where we're not going to go in and have rates increased in 2009 on top of this economy and our electric business. But in the longer run we're still comfortable with that growth rate.
Steve Fleishman - Catapult Capital
Okay. And then, do you still plan to be growing the dividend at the same rate that you've been growing it?
Jimmy Addison
Our Board will take up that discussion next week. And we'll be back to you, end of next week with a decision on that matter.
Steve Fleishman - Catapult Capital
Okay. Is then when you normally raise the dividend?
Jimmy Addison
It is.
Steve Fleishman - Catapult Capital
In February, okay.
Jimmy Addison

It is... we just... our Board meeting is actually the week after this earnings call this year. So normally, we're giving you all that information on this call. We release that piece separately for you.
Steve Fleishman - Catapult Capital
Okay, great. Thank you.
Jimmy Addison
You're welcome. Thank you.
Operator
And our next question will come from the line of Rodman with Dukane (ph). Please proceed.
Unidentified Analyst

My question, on the Georgia and the retail business there, could you just talk a little bit more about the competitive pressures you're seeing and margin impacts that maybe incurring? Are you seeing lower margins on the new customers that you are signing up, or just give us little more color on what's going on in that market?
Jimmy Addison

Yeah. I think when you get a material market. Many times market materials and folks get their processes down path, it tends to bring down the margins. But the larger driver I would say in addition to maturity of the market is that more customers are moving into fixed-rate plans. In those fixed-rate plans bear risk... less risks for the providers, for the marketers. I'm speaking generally now and not just about SCANA. And so, I think you're seeing lowers margins in that fixed-rate business.

A couple of years ago maybe 15% of our business was in fixed-rate, 85% variable. And today it's about 70-30 variable and fixed. And that's a reaction by customers to high gas prices post Katrina and Rita. And when the prices came back down, more folks are moving into the fixed rates, and are taking those risks off the table, and bearing the risk that price could go down further, and they'd be locked in at higher rates. But that's a part of the squeeze as well.

And then frankly, SCANA has been aggressive the last few months in pricing our product. And if you look at the large marketers, the top four, if you look at the total bill, we are either at the bottom or next to the bottom in the pricing of that in the last few months in an acquisition strategy.
Unidentified Analyst

Is this going from a predominantly variable to little more fixed-cost product change materially in anyway, the way you think about kind of collateral needs to provide that product? And are there any kind of credit issues we should think about in terms of maybe you're seeing more lines drawn or in the interim period, while you services those contracts going up into the heating seasons?
Jimmy Addison

Not really. I mean the folks are going to use, the gas are going to use no matter which plant they are under. Of course, when they do unlike the fixed option, we batch all of those and go out and put financial contracts behind those, so that we are hedged and there could be margin call on those if the prices change, but it's just not significant.
Unidentified Analyst
Okay. Thank you very much.
Operator
(Operator Instructions). And our next question will come from the line of Dan Jenkins with State of Wisconsin. Please proceed.
Dan Jenkins - State of Wisconsin
Good morning.
Jimmy Addison
Good morning, Dan.
Dan Jenkins - State of Wisconsin

One of you could give us a little more color on the decline in the fourth quarter and industrial and wholesale electric sales? Do you had any actual closures of large customers or is that mostly cutbacks unless there are certain areas that are more impacted than others?
Jimmy Addison

Yeah. Dan, as you noticed they are on the statistics in the back of the press release, our sales for the quarter to industrials were down about 9.5%. There is no one segment. We've analyzed that thoroughly. There have been a couple of operations that have closed until further notice, most of the impact though has been pairing back and there is no industry segment that is isolated too. We've looked at that thoroughly and it's just kind of across the board due to the demand.

I might just remind you that we have... we don't really have any single large segment that dominates our industrial market. The largest is probably the commercials, the chemical segment, which is about a third. But there are like eight or nine classes, SIC classes that make up our industrial segment. And most of them are 5 to 6% of the total industrials overall.

The other thing I would tell you that's important about this is the composition of our margins. And if you take the margins of SCE&G's electric business, about half of those margins now not sales but margins come from the residential sector. Another third come from the commercial sector, and only 12% of our margins come from the industrial sector and the remaining 5% comes from wholesale and another classes.

Though while the industrials are down, the margins are much thinner in that business because of the lower cost to serve and the way the rate structure is established. So you just don't see a pro-rata impact on the bottom line from a similar reduction in industrial that you would in residential.
Dan Jenkins - State of Wisconsin
Okay. How about the wholesale, it dropped by 42%?
Jimmy Addison

Yeah, that's... everyone else is experiencing what we have in our own maybe of territory, which is there are just not been a lot of demand outside of the area. And, of course, it was a mild quarter as well, although our severance quarter was mild also, but December was very mild here. But there just wasn't a demand for that off system. And frankly, where some of the demands being created in the northeast in the past and we've sold into other markets, it was not there in the other markets for us to sell wholesale either.
Dan Jenkins - State of Wisconsin
Okay. On the margins in electrical, it was up $0.41 for the year. I was wondering how much of that is attributable to the rate increase and how much to other factors, do you know how that splits up?
Jimmy Addison
Yeah, the vast majority is the rate increase. I think, 38 or $0.39 of it is was the rate increase.
Dan Jenkins - State of Wisconsin
Okay. And that one in effect in January right... so that, should be not an effect for '09 right?
Jimmy Addison
That's right. You've got a full year's work there.
Dan Jenkins - State of Wisconsin
Right, okay. And I was wondering have you, what's your CapEx budget for '09 and have you adjusted that any based on the economic situation?
Jimmy Addison

Well as I've said earlier, we have made some adjustments already, but those are ongoing and we are not going to release our detailed CapEx to you until we file the 10-K here in another few weeks. But we have made some reductions. And I think the important point at this time is that we're comfortable that we'll not have to go out and do another equity deal at this point. We can do with the equity deal we have under our belt earlier as part of the index deal and with the debt we have planned we should be in good shape from a CapEx lending perspective.
Dan Jenkins - State of Wisconsin
Okay. And kind of related to that, I know you have $100 million maturity on March 1. Do you have any plans to issue new debt in next quarter?
Jimmy Addison

Yeah. As I said earlier, what we're going to do is we're going to probably upsize that deal, and pay down some of the short-term debt. But that's really a kind of a dynamic issue. We're going to model the credit markets, we're going to model the commercial paper markets, watch those. At this point we're still sitting on $250 million of cash whereas this time of a year ago we probably had a less than 50. But we're still going to be conservative with that.

And we're going to need to decide how much cash are we willing to live with, how stable are the markets, and we'll determine at that point how much to do the deal for. But overall we expect to do in the balance of the year somewhere less than or at a maximum $450 million of debt.
Dan Jenkins - State of Wisconsin
Okay. Thank you.
Jimmy Addison
You're welcome.
Operator
(Operator Instructions). And our next question will come from the line of Jonathan Reeder with Wachovia. Please proceed.
Jonathan Reeder - Wachovia Securities

Good morning, gentlemen. I'm still trying to get I guess a better grasp on 2009 expectations. So, can you remind me, I might have missed it in your remarks, but is the next electric filing expected still in 2009, but new rates not until '10?
Jimmy Addison

Jonathan, as I've said in the past, we generally expect to be on a two to three year cycle. We will have had the existing rates in place for two years at the end of this year of 2009. But in this economy, we are not prepared yet to answer your question. Basically, we are not prepared yet to say when we will be in for new rates.

We do... our assumption though for the '09 guidance is that we do not expect new rates to impact '09 revenue. And we're going to monitor the situation, try to best understand the economy as we can and determine then where we might request new base rates at SCE&G.
Jonathan Reeder - Wachovia Securities

Okay. And then as far as the retail margin on the electric side, what's the assumption I guess for non-weather related electric usage? I know you said you're assuming flat customer growth, what about just on the usage side, absent the weather tick-up?
Jimmy Addison

Yeah, our assumption is, as I said we experienced in the tail end of the 2008 about 1 to 2% reduction in usage if you neutralize weather. And what we have done is taken that same assumption or that same result and modeled it for the entire year of '09. So, we're assuming that the consumption stays down for the whole year of 2009 as it did the last few months of 2008.

I'll tell you I gave you a range in my prepared comments of 1 to 2%, because that it really is a... there really is some art to that. It's not completely science. When you attempt to remove the impact of weather that is not an exact science. And so, we're trying to estimate consumption reduction, and we're using that to model it throughout the entire year 2009.
Jonathan Reeder - Wachovia Securities

Okay. And then, what about just in general, your expectations I guess, for an economic recovery? Are you kind of modeling a stabilization in the second half and no pick up whatsoever in say Q4 or I guess, what are you kind of seeing on the general landscape there?
Jimmy Addison

Well, we don't, of course, have access to anything that you don't. I read what you read. But our assumptions are we're going to stay conservative to this. And we're going to assume that we don't add another residential customer or commercial customer beyond January 1. And we know we're adding some.

So, we're going to... my point is that we're really trying to be conservative about these assumptions. And to give you much more detail than we have in the past about what our assumptions are, so that you can build your own models and make your assumptions of what they might be. That's why we moved to a $0.30 band on our guidance.

And again our commitment is as we move through the year assuming these things become clear I sure hope that we'll... that we can come back and narrow that band, and firm up some of these assumptions for you.
Jonathan Reeder - Wachovia Securities
Thank you.
Jimmy Addison

About earnings guidance, we tend to be, as we do in most things, fairly conservative. And we've been providing guidance since 2000. This will be the 10th year we provided guidance. And every year that we provided guidance with the exception of one, we've met our original guidance.

That one year was '06. We came along later in the year and revised it because of the loss of two very large industrial customers. One related to a train accident, and a chemicals spill that shut down a plant, and very temperate weather. And then, we've met that revised guidance.
But, we're really trying to layout for all of you folks the detailed assumptions, and what we've assumed going into there. So we hope to be able to revise it during the year.
Jonathan Reeder - Wachovia Securities

Yeah. I mean, I would definitely agree. I mean, it seems like you've taken very conservative approach to '09. So, I'm wondering like if all these, I guess, almost worst case, I mean I don't want to call a worst case scenario, but if all these forecasts hold true, I mean does that put us then I mean in the middle of the range or would that put us towards the lower end of your range?
Jimmy Addison
That's a great question. But, I think I'll wait till later in the year to announce that.
Jonathan Reeder - Wachovia Securities

Alright, got you. And then, I guess one last thing, and I'm not sure how much more you will be help me out. But going back to Steve's question on the 4 to 6% annual EPS growth target, I mean looking at 2009, if we end up in the middle of the range '10, would we expect the 4 to 6% off of that base or do you expect that I guess kind of catch up from the last year and say 2010 or 2011?
Jimmy Addison

Yeah, and that's really going to be driven by your earlier question about the base rate increase in the electric business and that's going to have to be affected before we get back, recover that catch-up.
Jonathan Reeder - Wachovia Securities
Okay. But ultimately, I guess it sounds like once the economy gets I guess backup and running, and you get I guess the rate release, you expect to kind of makeup for this somewhat last year in 2009?
Jimmy Addison

Yeah, and the reason is that it's really driven by underlying customer growth and rate base growth. And yesterday we got a very strategic decision from the Public Service Commission about the Base Load Review Act. We now have that in our hands to move forward with that.

We know what the drivers of that will be, that's where a significant piece of our rate base growth is coming. The fact is the core of your question is that we're under earnings allowed return right now in the electric business and until that is re-established through the economy recovering and through periodic base increase and base rates every two to three years, we'll not be back into that band.

But the long-term core growth has not changed. I mean it's slowed, but the customers still move here, the rate base is expanding, we've got $400 million of environmental projects that are not in rates today, that will need to be moved in rates at some point of course they are earnings AFC during the interim. But nothing has changed in our underlying core strategy and for a long-term stability of the southeast.
Jonathan Reeder - Wachovia Securities
Okay, got you. Thanks so much for the time.
Jimmy Addison
You're very welcome.
Operator
This concludes the question-and-answer portion of today's conference. I would now like to turn the call back over to Mr. Jimmy Addison for any closing remarks.
Jimmy Addison

Thank you very much. We appreciate all of your interests, continuing interests in our company here. And we expect to be back to you in the near term once we get an order out of the Public Service Commission with more details on the nuclear project and we'll keep you updated quarterly. Thank you.

title: SCANA Corporation Q1 2009 Earnings Call Transcript
body: SCANA Corporation (NYSE:SCG) Q1 2009 Earnings Call Transcript April 23, 2009  2:00 PM ET
Executives
Betty Best – Director of Financial Planning and IR
Jimmy Addison – SVP and CFO
Analysts
Michael Lapides – Goldman Sachs
Steve Fleishman – Catapult
Paul Patterson – Glenrock Associates
Dan Jenkins – State of Wisconsin Investments
Chris Shelton – Millennium
Jim Ferguson – AIG
Operator

Good day, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you for standing by. My name is Michelle, and I will be your conference facilitator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the SCANA Corporation Conference Call.

All lines have been placed on mute to prevent any background noise. After the speakers' remarks there will be a question-and-answer period. (Operator instructions) As a reminder this conference call is being recorded on Thursday, April 23rd. Anyone who does not consent to the taping may drop off the line at this time.
I would now like to turn the call over to Betty Best, Director of Financial Planning and Investor Relations.
Betty Best

Thanks, Michelle, and good afternoon. I’d like to welcome everyone to our earnings conference call, including those who are joining us on the webcast. Earlier today, we announced financial results for the first quarter of 2009. In just a minute, Jimmy Addison, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer will review those results and respond to questions.

The earnings press release that we will refer to in this conference call is available on our Web site at scana.com. I would like to remind everyone that certain statements that may be made during today's call which are not statements of historical fact are considered forward-looking statements and are subject to a number of risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those indicated by such forward-looking statements, including the risks and uncertainties discussed in the company's SEC filings. The company does not recognize an obligation to update any forward-looking statements.
I will now turn the call over to Jimmy.
Jimmy Addison

Thanks, Betty, and good afternoon. I’d also like to welcome each of you to our call. SCANA reported first quarter earnings on a GAAP basis of $114 million or $0.94 per share compared to $109 million or $0.94 per share in the first quarter of 2008. This break even results were due primarily to lower operating and maintenance expenses and favorable weather in our electric service territory, which effectively offset the negative impact of lower natural gas margins, lower industrial and all system sales and share dilution.

Given the current economic conditions and the impact of dilution, we’re very pleased with these first quarter results. As we looked to the remainder of 2009, we remained cautiously optimistic that the underlying strength of our service territories and our continued company wide cost control efforts will allow us to deliver solid financial results while still producing the level of service our customers have come to expect.

Now, I’d like to review the first quarter results for our principle lines of business. As a reminder, the majority of SCANA operations are regulated. Our regulated utility businesses; SCE&G, PSNC Energy, and Carolina Gas Transmission, collectively represent more than 90% of our total assets and annual earnings per share.

SCE&G, our largest subsidiary, reported earnings of $62 million or $0.51 per share compared to $60 million or $0.51 per share in the same quarter last year. These break even results are attributable to lower O&M expenses and favorable weather in our electric service territory, which also set the negative impact of lower natural gas margins and share dilution.

As of March 31 of this year, SCE&G was serving approximately 652,000 electric customers, which represents a 1.4% increase during the past year. Over that same period, SCE&G’s natural gas customer base increased 1.3% to approximately 309,000.

Yesterday, the South Carolina Public Service Commission approved an adjustment in the fuel component of SCE&G’s electric base rates that will allow fuel recovery of higher fuel costs that were incurred for fuel to operate the company’s electric generating plants over the past twelve months.

In recognition of the impact that rising energy cost are having on our customers, we agreed to spread the recovery of those costs over a three year period. And in consideration of the extended period, we’re allowed to collect interest on the deferred balance. The Public Service Commission and the Office of Regulatory Staff, review SCE&G electric fuel costs at least annually and, if appropriate, the PSC authorizes an adjustment to the fuel component of rates to reflect increases or decreases in those costs.

Also yesterday, SCE&G and the city of Orangeburg reached an agreement for SCE&G to continue serving wholesale electric power needs under the existing agreement by extension through December 31, 2010. Orangeburg, long considered part of our native load, has been served by SCE&G and it’s predecessor since 1919. SCE&G has served Orangeburg under the existing agreement with approximately 190 megawatts of capacity since May 2001.

In 2006, Orangeburg solicited competitive proposals for supply beginning 2009 from SCE&G and other providers. And it initially awarded the contract to another supplier. However, prior to commencement of service with the new supplier, Orangeburg decided to seek continued service from SCE&G under this mutually beneficial extension.

PSNC Energy, our retail natural gas distribution company in North Carolina, reported earnings for the first quarter of $30 million or $0.25 per share compared to $28 million or $0.24 per share in the same quarter in 2008. That improvement was due mainly to new rates effective in November of last year, more than offsetting the share dilution. At March 31, 2009, PSNC Energy was serving approximately 469,000 natural gas customers, an increase of 1.8% over the last 12 months.

SCANA Energy, our retail natural gas marketing business in Georgia, reported earnings of $22 million or $0.18 per share in the first quarter of 2009, compared to $22 million or $0.19 per share in the first quarter of 2008. This decline is also due primarily to dilution. At March 31, 2009, SCANA Energy was serving approximately 465,000 customers in Georgia, maintaining its position as the second largest natural gas marketer in the state.

SCANA Energy was again selected to serve as the regulated provider for the fourth consecutive two-year term beginning September 1st of this year. We’re pleased to continue in this important role serving the elderly and low income citizens of Georgia. SCANA Energy has served as the State’s only regulated provider since market deregulation, and currently provides service to approximately 100,000 customers.

Carolina Gas Transmission, our interstate natural gas transmission subsidiary, recorded earnings of $0.02 per share, unchanged in the same quarter last year. We continue to be pleased with the earnings stability we are seeing at CGT with its transportation only business model. We expect to see its earnings remain very consistent going forward and we forecast $0.07 per share on earnings for full 2009.

SCANA’s corporate and other businesses, which include SCANA Communications, ServiceCare, SCANA Energy Marketing, and the Holding Company reported a combined loss of $0.02 per share, essentially break even when compared to the same quarter of last year.

We have completed two significant financings in the first quarter 2009 with the closing of the $102 million follow-on equity offering that was executed in conjunction with the addition of SCANA to the S&P 500 index, and the $175 million 30-year first mortgage bond offering at SCE&G. We’re pleased with the reception of our strategy for both the equity and debt markets in these uncertain market conditions. As you were well aware, our ability to access capital markets is a key part of our financial strategy as we implement our nuclear plans.

For the remainder of 2009, we’re currently planning a financing of approximately $250 million of SCE&G’s first mortgage bonds in the second half of this year. Additionally, we’re continuing to fulfill our equity needs by issuing new shares through our 401-K in dividend reinvestment plans. These plans will provide an estimated $85 million of equity during 2009, and we anticipate keeping this strategy in place for the foreseeable future. The minimally dilutive effect of these shares had been considered in our earnings guidance.

Yesterday, S&P announced a downgrade in our credit ratings. While we’re disappointed in these downgrades, were pleased that they recognize the strength of SCE&G’s secured ratings and maintained the A minus rating and changed the outlook from negative to stable.

From a practical stand point, we expect the vast majority of our debt needs to be fulfilled through SCE&G first mortgage bonds and short term borrowings of commercial paper. And are pleased that the overhang of the negative outlook is removed and the rating has been maintained to the A minus level.

With these solid first quarter results, we are reaffirming our 2009 earnings guidance of $2.65 to $2.95 per share, and continue to target a long term average annual earnings growth rate of 4% to 6%. We believe that with the continued uncertain economy, it is premature to adjust our guidance at this time, and we anticipate narrowing the range later in the year.

Keep in mind our guidance assumes normal weather in our electric and natural gas service area towards for the remainder of the year, and excludes any potential impact from changes in accounting principles or certain gains or losses from investing activities, litigation, and sales of assets. Other factors that may impact future earnings are discussed in our SEC filings.

Turning now to a few important regulatory filings in the coming months that I would like to address, on May 15th we will file our first quarterly status report with the Office Regulatory Staff as required under our recent base load review order associated with our new nuclear activities. This report will provide a detailed update our capital costs incurred and updated milestones for our new nuclear project. A copy of this report will be available on our Web site.

On May 29th we also expect to submit our initial annual revised rate adjustment filing with the Commission for the annual recovery of financing costs related to CWID [ph] The requested rate adjustments will be based on the incremental CWID incurred from the May 2008 filing through June 30, 2009, and on an updated capital structure. The ROE is set at 11%. New rates under this filing will go into effect October 30th of this year after review by the ORS and approval by the PSC.

And finally, I would like to thank everyone who participated in our analyst day event at V.C. Summer on April 2nd. We had a tremendous response with approximately 150 analysts participating in some fashion.

A replay of the webcast, the detailed presentations, and a transcript of the event are available at scana.com on the webcast and presentations page. If you have not had a chance to review this material, I would strongly encourage you to do so as we’ve provided a detailed update on our new nuclear strategy and pre-construction process, as well as recent and upcoming regulatory activities.
If you have any questions about these materials or our earning’s results discussed here today, please contact our investor relations office
That concludes our prepared remarks and I'll now be glad to respond to any questions you may have.
Question-and-Answer Session
Operator
(Operator instructions) Your first question comes from the line of Michael Lapides of Goldman Sachs. Please proceed.
Michael Lapides – Goldman Sachs

Hey, guys. Congrats on a good quarter. Quick question, O&M down a ton year-over-year, first quarter to first quarter. Can you talk a little bit about that? Which segment did you – where did that occur? Meaning which of your businesses? How recurring is that difference when I think about the rest of 2009 or even first quarter of 2010?
Jimmy Addison

Sure, Michael. First of all, it really occurred across all of our businesses. It was a conscious effort. You’ve heard us talk about this for the last two or three quarters as it was obvious we were heading into a recessionary period. And our strategy has been to control those O&M costs that we can and restrain those that would not have an impact on safety, reliability, or customer service. And that's what we've done.

So it's really occurred across all of our businesses. There have been general reductions. For example, one of the more tangible ones is we only provided salary increases this year for predominantly our hourly employees. So the salary employees, the management, et cetera have not had wage increases over the last 14 plus months now.

With the slow down of the economy, we have in the past, with the robust growth we've had, we’ve had to rely on external contractors to do a lot of the expansion work. And with the slow down, we've been able to remove some of those contractors from the system, use our existing personnel to do more of the construction work. So some of that cost is now being capitalized from our existing personnel where in the past it was more O&M expense.

Maybe a little surprising, bad debt expense is down. We're really encouraged by where we are to this point. We're still cautiously optimistic for quarter-over-quarter, that's over $4 million from a quarter-over-quarter year apart. And we attribute a lot of that to our enhanced process season in the Georgia market; enhanced security there.
We also attribute it to – a lot of it to lower commodity cost, especially on the GAAP side. The bills were substantially less than they were a year ago with the falling cost.

And then finally, with our – as you’ve seen our guidance for 2009, we obviously are in a year where we're not expecting growth year-over-year. And so our incentive targets for our incentive compensation throughout our employee base, including the management team, the board has set those at staggered targets that start at the middle of our earnings guidance and go up to the top of our earnings guidance. And so, we're clearly not expecting at the middle of the guidance to hit some of those. So we’ve got lower incentive CompCost recorded to date.

So that's a long answer to your question. But some of those we expect to be recurring, at least as long as the economy is in this kind of condition. And as the economy returns, we would expect some of these costs to come back. For example, the example I gave you about using our personnel to do construction cost. As we get to a more robust growth rate, we will have to bring back some contractors. And therefore our cost will go back up with those. But some of it will be more directly correlated to the economy.
Michael Lapides – Goldman Sachs
Got it. Okay. Thank you, Jimmy.
Jimmy Addison
You're welcome.
Operator
Your next question comes from the line of Steve Fleishman of Catapult. Please proceed.
Steve Fleishman – Catapult
Hi, guys.
Jimmy Addison
Hi, Steve.
Steve Fleishman – Catapult
Can you hear me okay?
Jimmy Addison
Yes.
Steve Fleishman – Catapult
Okay. Sorry. First, just a question on the weather impact because last year I think, you had below normal weather?
Jimmy Addison
That's correct.
Steve Fleishman – Catapult
So can you give us some sense? When you talk about favorable weather, is that primarily a benefit versus last year or was actually favorable versus normal?
Jimmy Addison

It's a little of both, Steve. It's $0.08 year-over-year, and about $0.05 of that is getting back to normal. So if you took ‘08’s quarter, you have to add $0.05 to get back to normal. And so we were about $0.03 above normal for the quarter.
Steve Fleishman – Catapult
Got you. Okay. When you gave guidance for 2009, you talked a lot about conservative assumptions that you incorporated.
Jimmy Addison
Right.
Steve Fleishman – Catapult
A couple things, one of them was this contract, the Orangeburg contract going away which you’ve now resolved.
Jimmy Addison
Right.
Steve Fleishman – Catapult
I think another was just – you needed to assume cost cutting which you seem to be doing extremely well. Maybe the industrial sales have been worse than you expected?
Jimmy Addison
Well, yes–
Steve Fleishman – Catapult
Is that a fair characterization of the gives and takes so far this year?
Jimmy Addison

It is. And the thing that I would say about the industrials is, if you remember our assumptions as we laid it out, we said what we did at the time that we gave guidance is we took every known; any plants that were idle at the time or any that have reduced production in any publicly known announcements, anything we knew from working with our customers. And we assumed that was at that level for the remainder of the year. So to the extent that some things got a little worse, in a few cases they have, that was not in our forecast. So that's a little bit of the downside.

It's an interesting thing though. If you look in our press release, you see on the unit sales in industrials were down a little over 18%. But I would tell you – I would remind you that only about 12% of our electric margins come from industrials. And in the industrial contracts they all have minimum demand takes.

And so our revenues are only down about half of that unit cost reduction. So for the units that were down about 18.5%, our revenue is only down about 9%. The cost of minimum takes are in all those contracts that are there to justify the investment of the equipment to initially serve the industrial customer.
Steve Fleishman – Catapult
That's interesting.
Jimmy Addison
Yes. That helps moderate it, and fairly typical in the business.
Steve Fleishman – Catapult

Okay. I guess just get one other question on the O&M savings. To degree that – let’s say the economy stays as it is, quite weak, is this the kind of runway of O&M that could be potentially for the year? Or is this just – could it – it really is very significant savings.
Jimmy Addison

Yes, it is. And again, the bad debt was a significant piece of it. If the economy stays like this for a real extended period of time, even given the lower commodity cost and the benefit there, just pure credit quality will move that back up at some point directionally now. I don’t know that it would move it back up to the same level of a year ago. But I do believe that directionally, we’ll be in good shape compared to last year. I don't know if it will be quite – be able to maintain it quite at this level as we move throughout the year.
Steve Fleishman – Catapult
Okay.
Jimmy Addison
And certainly, at some point I hope the economy starts to recover. I hope we're able to reconsider salary increases for the employee base. It's really, really working hard.
Steve Fleishman – Catapult
Okay. Thank you.
Jimmy Addison
You're welcome.
Operator
Your next question comes from the line of Paul Patterson of Glenrock Associates. Please proceed.
Paul Patterson – Glenrock Associates
Hi, guys.
Jimmy Addison
Hello, Paul.
Paul Patterson – Glenrock Associates

Not to focus too much on the O&M, but I noticed that unemployment rate in South Carolina was one of the biggest states – biggest increases for a state recently. I was wondering, was that in your conservative guidance in terms of what we might be seeing in terms of sales growth? And how does that impact commercial and residential?
Jimmy Addison

The unemployment rate is up above 10%. It is one of the highest in the nation. And it's been fairly close to that. We’ve not seen a significant increase in conservation other than what we based the plan on earlier.

In the markets that we serve principally – you're getting a state-wide unemployment right there in the markets that we serve from the electric business; principally Colombia, Charleston, Aiken, Augusta. I don't know the exact unemployment rates in those areas, but I think there's been more stability in those areas. Colombia itself is basically made up of State government, the army base – largest basic training army base in the country, and the university. And not a huge amount of corporate headquarters and things of that nature.

And of course, Charleston has continued to perform fairly well. Some of the counties that we have very little service in have a 20 plus percent unemployment rate and there's very little population saturation in those counties. Paul Patterson – Glenrock Associates

Okay. Then on the filing at the office of regulatory staff, the update, is it likely that they’ll give you a substantial change? Or can you give us any of the flavor for or do we just have to wait until it comes out?
Jimmy Addison
I'm not sure I understand your question.
Paul Patterson – Glenrock Associates
I guess what I'm asking is, the filing that you’re going to be making, which I believe was an update of your CapEx, et cetera, correct?
Jimmy Addison
Yes. On May 15th
Paul Patterson – Glenrock Associates
Yes.
Jimmy Addison
Okay.

Jimmy Addison
Well, this is a routine filing that we’re required to do every quarter. We make a filing.
Paul Patterson – Glenrock Associates
Sure.
Jimmy Addison

We're not making it because we have some expected change. We’re just making it because it's the first filing under the requirement. And we'll do that every quarter. I don't know of anything at this point that's a material change.
Paul Patterson – Glenrock Associates

Okay. I was just wondering if there's was any – if there’d be a change in the outlook at all. And finally, with respect to the equity offering, it looks like you guys are set for 2009. When do you think will be the earliest time you’d come back for a regular equity offering?
Jimmy Addison

Paul Patterson – Glenrock Associates

Jimmy Addison

Good afternoon.

Yes.

Dan Jenkins – State of Wisconsin Investments
Okay. So it’s more of a cash flow impact than earnings.

Yes. The industrials – the industrials were down about $0.02 per share and the residential and commercial were down about $0.04 per share so about $0.06 per share in total.

Right. Could you give a little color on just what are you seeing from your economy, in your service territory? Is it better, worst, the same? Well, certainly as we were – as I was discussing a few minutes ago, the unemployment rate is higher statewide. We have seen a mixture of some industrials – some additional industrial kind of idling of facilities or cutting back of facilities. We’ve seen some – recently some announcements of a few industrial focus of expansions so things of that nature. So there’s really a mixture right now. I really would not characterize it much different than what I read nationally.

Okay. Thank you.
